  • The Act authorized approximately $45.5 billion in funding between FY2010 and FY2013, with many provisions expiring at the end of FY2013.

• President Obama's FY2013 budget request sought increased funding for research and STEM education, but at levels below those authorized by COMPETES 2010.
  • The request included specific funding for the Regional Innovation Program and the NSF's Sustainable Chemistry program, but did not seek funding for several other authorized programs.

• FY2013 appropriations were affected by sequestration and rescissions, resulting in funding levels below FY2010 for many COMPETES 2010 accounts.
  • The gap between authorized and appropriated funding widened in FY2013, raising concerns about future funding and reauthorization.

• The COMPETES acts were designed to improve U.S. competitiveness through increased funding for research and STEM education, but faced opposition due to cost concerns and differing policy preferences.
  • The debate continues on the best federal approach to fostering scientific and technological innovation and national competitiveness.

<summary>

  * The 2008 amendments expanded the Act to include nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws.

  * Others defend the Act as a necessary conservation tool to combat illegal trade.

* The declaration requirements are controversial, with calls for modifications to ease compliance.

  * APHIS has initiated a pilot program to test blanket declarations, but it was not successful.

* Exercising due care is crucial for importers to avoid penalties under the Act.
  * Due care involves verifying the legality of imported plants and plant products.
  * The standard of due care varies based on the knowledge and responsibility of the importer.

<summary>
* Farming is a cyclical business with price swings influenced by factors like weather, export demand, and foreign subsidies.
    * Farmers often operate at a loss when prices drop, drawing down resources.
    * U.S. producers have received federal intervention for nearly 70 years to support prices and incomes.
    * Deficiency payments linked to target prices were a prominent form of aid between 1973 and 1995.
    * The FAIR Act of 1996 replaced these with fixed production flexibility contract (PFC) payments.

* The 1996 Act introduced marketing assistance loans as a form of counter-cyclical support.
    * Farmers could pledge stored commodities as collateral for USDA loans.
    * Loans were set at lower rates, allowing repayment at less than the original rate when market prices were low.
    * Loan deficiency payments (LDP) were available for those not taking USDA loans.
    * The subsidy increased as market prices dropped below the loan rate.

* The 1996 farm bill's safety net was deemed inadequate, leading to emergency "market loss payments."
    * These payments supplemented marketing loans and fixed PFC payments.
    * Payments were made in response to low prices and incomes.
    * Congress incorporated new counter-cyclical measures into standing law in 2002.
    * The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA) of 2002 restored target prices and deficiency payments.

* FSRIA introduced fixed "direct payments" and maintained marketing assistance loans and LDPs.
    * The law covered the 2002-2007 crop years.
    * Soybeans and minor oilseeds were brought under the support program rules.
    * Peanut support was redesigned to operate like grains, oilseeds, and cotton.
    * Payments were based on 85% of each farm's base production.

* The new counter-cyclical program calculated deficiency payments based on target prices.
    * Payments were not contingent on annual planting rules.
    * Farmers could plant any crops except most fruits and vegetables.
    * Dairy farmers received "national dairy market loss payments" under certain conditions.
    * Contracts for dairy payments expired on September 30, 2005.

* Alternative designs for counter-cyclical assistance were discussed.
    * One plan triggered payments based on state-level cash receipts.
    * Another plan established a "national target income" for each major crop.
    * The Congressional Budget Office estimated FSRIA's commodity support provisions at $98.9 billion over 6 years.

<summary>
* Over the past decade, advancements in protein separation techniques and peptide analysis by mass spectrometry have significantly improved proteome analysis.
  * Current ion trap mass spectrometers are highly sensitive, enabling the identification of hundreds of proteins in a single LC-MS/MS analysis.
* Comprehensive protein profiling of complex samples remains challenging due to the wide concentration range of proteins.
  * To improve proteome coverage, samples are often fractionated at the protein or peptide level, or both.
* Undersampling occurs when the complexity of tryptic digests exceeds the analytical capacity of the mass spectrometer.
  * This results in variable protein identification lists, raising concerns about the reproducibility of proteomics.
* Strategies to improve proteome coverage include repetitive LC-MS/MS analyses and additional protein prefractionation.
  * These methods have been integrated into diverse analyses of complex proteomes by multiple laboratories.
* The study compared gelC-MS/MS with repetitive LC-MS/MS analysis and additional protein prefractionation using cancer cell lysates.
  * The 3-D method, which included prefractionation, showed improved proteome coverage compared to the repetitive analysis of fractions from the 2-D method.
* The 3-D method identified 22% more proteins than the 2-D/repetitive method using equal instrument time.
  * It also identified more unique peptides for low-abundance proteins compared to the cumulative 2-D method data.
* Repetitive analysis improved proteome coverage but lacked mechanisms to reduce repeated sampling of abundant ions.
  * The 3-D method's additional protein separation step was more efficient in utilizing mass spectrometer time.
* The study highlighted the importance of balancing depth of analysis with sample throughput and proteome analysis cost.
  * Longer HPLC gradients or additional fractionation usually confer benefits in terms of depth of analysis.
* The reproducibility of protein lists between the two methods was high, with most differences due to database and software limitations.
  * Improved databases and software tools are needed for better identification and display of unique proteins within protein families.
* The study concluded that additional prefractionation with microsol IEF substantially increased proteome coverage and sequence coverage.
  * This method minimized undersampling during data acquisition, leading to high reproducibility of protein lists.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study compared postoperative bleeding rates between tonsillectomy and submucosal uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (SMUPPP) procedures.
  • Tonsillectomy had a higher incidence of secondary, delayed hemorrhage (5.05%) compared to SMUPPP (1.45%).
  • The difference in bleeding rates was attributed to the surgical techniques, particularly the use of suturing in SMUPPP.

• Suturing techniques in SMUPPP may reduce postoperative bleeding.
  • Suturing both muscular and mucosal layers of the tonsillar fossa in SMUPPP decreased bleeding incidence.
  • Bipolar cauterization followed by tacking with 3-0 vicryl sutures was effective in reducing bleeding.

• The study suggests adopting SMUPPP suturing techniques in tonsillectomy to lower hemorrhage rates.
  • Double-layer closure and approximating muscular and mucosal layers can aid in postoperative healing.
  • Routine use of SMUPPP suturing techniques in tonsillectomy patients is recommended to reduce postoperative hemorrhage.
</summary>

* The document discusses the synthesis of β-lactams and γ-lactams using sulfone-substituted anhydrides.
  * These lactams are crucial intermediates in pharmaceuticals and natural products.
  * The synthesis involves Mannich-type reactions and four-component reactions (4CRs).
  * The reactions proceed via a Mannich-like mechanism involving enol tautomers.

* The research explores the reactivity of variously substituted anhydrides.
  * Aryl, thioaryl, and cyano-substituted anhydrides show different reactivities.
  * Electron-withdrawing groups increase reactivity.
  * Diastereoselectivity varies with different substituents.

* Sulfone-substituted anhydrides are developed for Mannich reactions.
  * These anhydrides show similar reactivity to nitrile-substituted anhydrides.
  * The steric requirements differ significantly.
  * The reactions yield β-lactams and γ-lactams with high diastereoselectivity.

* The synthesis of anhydrides 3a-d is achieved from readily available materials.
  * Anhydride 3a is synthesized via conjugate addition and cyclization.
  * Anhydrides 3b-d are synthesized through Michael addition and ester cleavage.
  * These anhydrides react with imines to form lactams.

* The document reports on the stereochemical outcomes of the reactions.

  * Anti-configured carboxylic acids are kinetic products.
  * Decarboxylation leads to thermodynamically preferred anti-sulfones.

* The reactions tolerate a variety of non-enolizable aldehydes and amines.
  * Commercially available imines improve yields.
  * Methyl-substituted anhydrides provide trisubstituted lactams.
  * Substitution on the anhydride offers excellent facial selectivity.

* The research aims to develop enantioselective Michael additions.
  * Sulfone acetate 8 is used to provide single enantiomers.
  * This would yield enantiomerically pure lactam products.
  * The methodology is robust and applicable to various targets.

* The synthesis is applied to a formal synthesis of (±)-isoretronecanol.
  * The reaction involves imine 16 and anhydride 3a.
  * Ring-closing metathesis forms the pyrrolizidine core.

<summary>
* The morbidity of breast cancer is increasing, with more young people at risk, and it remains the leading cause of death among women in China.
  * Early detection and molecular analysis are crucial for effective treatment.
  * MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play significant roles in breast cancer development and progression.
  * miRNAs like mir-125a, mir-206, and mir-145 act as tumor suppressors, while mir-21 and mir-10b function as oncogenes.
  
* The study examined the expression of specific miRNAs in breast cancer tissues and their relationship with clinical pathology.
  * mir-125a, mir-206, and mir-145 showed lower expression in cancer tissues compared to normal tissues.
  * mir-21 and mir-10b exhibited higher expression in cancer tissues.
  * The expression levels of these miRNAs were correlated with various clinical factors like tumor size and lymph node metastasis.

* mir-125a can inhibit breast cancer cell metastasis by affecting HER-2 and HER-3 protein levels.
  * It is negatively associated with HER-2, suggesting a regulatory role.
  * mir-125a expression increases with HDAC inhibitor treatment, indicating potential therapeutic applications.
  * It may help develop new anti-HER-2 drugs and overcome resistance to Herceptin.

* mir-206 is linked to muscle differentiation and inhibits breast cancer cell proliferation.
  * It affects ER and ER co-regulatory proteins via the EGF/MAPK pathway.
  * mir-206 is associated with small tumors and negative ER, PR, and HER-2 expression.
  * It could be a target for TNBC treatment and inhibit positive ER lines.

* mir-145 is negatively correlated with tumor size and lymph node metastasis.
  * It affects target genes like c-Myc and Sox2, inhibiting tumor cell hyperplasia.
  * mir-145 is associated with negative ER, HER-2, and Top 2a expression.
  * It may serve as a target for TNBC treatment and influence chemotherapy resistance.

* mir-21 is overexpressed in breast cancer and linked to lymph node metastasis and positive HER-2 expression.
  * It regulates anti-oncogenes like TPM1 and Bcl-2, promoting cancer cell metastasis.
  * mir-21 is an independent prognostic factor and associated with trastuzumab resistance.
  * It is positively related to Top 2a expression, influencing chemotherapy outcomes.

<summary>
• The study investigates the role of tissue transglutaminase (TGM2) in the context of reversible acute rejection and chronic allograft injury (CAI) in a rat model.
    • TGM2 is overexpressed by mononuclear leukocytes, particularly activated monocytes, in the vascular bed of renal allografts during acute rejection.
    • Elevated TGM2 mRNA levels are observed in allograft tissues, but no significant increase in protein levels is detected, suggesting potential post-transcriptional modifications or degradation.
    • The study explores the potential role of TGM2 in apoptosis and its contribution to the reversion of acute rejection, although its exact function remains unclear.
    • Cystamine, a transglutaminase inhibitor, was used to assess its impact on CAI, but no significant protective effects were observed within the study period.

• The experimental model used involves transplantation of kidneys from Fischer-344 to Lewis rat strains, allowing the study of acute rejection and CAI without immunosuppression.
    • The model shows a strong mononuclear infiltration during acute rejection, with leukocytes accumulating in blood vessels and interacting with endothelial cells.
    • TGM2 expression is linked to apoptosis, with increased levels of activated caspase-3 observed in leukocytes from allografts, suggesting a potential role in cell death regulation.
    • The study highlights the complexity of TGM2's functions, including its involvement in apoptosis, cell adhesion, and vascular remodeling, which require further investigation.
    • Despite the lack of significant findings regarding cystamine's effect, the study provides insights into the early phases of CAI and the potential involvement of TGM2.

• The study acknowledges limitations, including the use of a single dose of cystamine and the lack of immunosuppression, which may not fully represent clinical transplantation scenarios.
    • The experimental model focuses on the early phase post-transplantation, complementing other studies that investigate end-stage CAI.
    • The study suggests that TGM2 may serve as a marker for CAI, reflecting changes in cellular composition, but its active contribution to CAI pathogenesis remains uncertain.
    • Future research is needed to explore the diverse functions of TGM2 in acute and chronic allograft rejection, as well as the potential use of more specific inhibitors.
    • The findings contribute to the understanding of TGM2's role in allograft rejection and highlight the need for further investigation into its therapeutic potential.
</summary

<summary>
• The study investigates the clearance of endothelial microparticles (EMPs) using continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) in a model system.
  • EMPs were prepared from endothelial cells and characterized using flow cytometry and transmission electron microscopy.
  • EMPs were introduced into an IV bag and circulated through a CVVH filter to simulate patient conditions.
  • The study aimed to assess the potential of CVVH as a therapeutic intervention for acute lung injury (ALI) by removing EMPs.

• EMP clearance was measured over time, showing rapid reduction in EMP levels within the first 30 minutes.
  • EMP levels decreased to 29% of the starting concentration within 40 minutes and remained constant thereafter.
  • Dialysate analysis revealed that only 5.7% of the original EMP concentration was present after 4 hours of dialysis.
  • The study suggests that EMP sequestration within the CVVH filter is a saturable phenomenon.

• Limitations of the model include differences in volume between human circulation and the CVVH circuit.
  • The model does not account for ongoing EMP generation in patients, requiring non-saturable clearance methods.
  • Convection and pressure gradient forces were not modeled, which could enhance EMP clearance.
  • The absence of plasma oncotic elements in the model is considered representative of unbound plasma EMPs in human disease.

• The study proposes potential improvements for EMP clearance using CVVH.
  • Frequent changing of the CVVH filter may overcome saturation limitations.
  • Conjugating endothelium-specific antibodies to CVVH filters could enhance selective EMP binding.
  • Combining selective filters with convection and pressure gradients may prolong EMP clearance.

• Clinical implications of CVVH in ALI management are discussed.
  • CVVH may prevent or minimize volume overload during critical illness resuscitation.
  • Early CVVH could target both molecular and iatrogenic components of ALI.
  • Clinical trials and animal studies support the protective role of CVVH in ALI management.

• Future research directions include patient studies and animal models.
  • Assaying patients pre- and post-dialysis to observe EMP concentration effects is planned.
  • Rodent models of EMP-induced ALI will be used to examine efficacy and EMP thresholds.
  • The study suggests that standard dialysis alone may be effective for EMP removal due to their small size.

• The authors declare no funding or benefits from industry for this study.
  • The study was conducted independently without external financial support.

<summary>
• The study focused on patients with chronic stable angina, evaluating the effects of sublingual nitroglycerin spray on exercise tolerance.
  • Patients with frequent angina experience greater physical limitations and decreased quality of life.
  • The study aimed to assess the impact of nitroglycerin spray on time to onset of angina and exercise-induced myocardial ischemia.

• The study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover, dose-ranging multicenter trial.
  • Conducted at four centers in the United States, it adhered to international guidelines for good clinical practice.
  • A total of 51 patients were enrolled, with a focus on those with documented coronary artery disease and stable angina.

• Results showed a dose-dependent increase in time to onset of moderate angina with nitroglycerin spray.
  • The 1.6 mg dose showed the most pronounced improvement compared to placebo.
  • The spray was generally well-tolerated, with mild to moderate adverse events like headache and dizziness.

• The study highlighted the importance of lifestyle modifications and supervised exercise therapy in managing stable angina.
  • Sublingual nitroglycerin was found to increase physical exercise tolerance.
  • This improvement may allow for greater exertion before the onset of angina.

• The study supports the use of sublingual nitroglycerin spray as part of optimal medical therapy for stable angina.
  • It may also benefit patients with persistent angina post-revascularization.
  • Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term benefits on exercise duration and quality of life.

• Current guidelines emphasize medical therapy for stable angina, with revascularization not showing significant differences in serious adverse events.
  • Optimal medical therapy, including beta-blockers and statins, is effective in controlling symptoms and reducing cardiac event risks.
  • The study aligns with findings that medical therapy can be as effective as revascularization in managing stable angina.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study investigates the antifungal properties of ProRoot MTA and MTA-Angelus against Candida albicans in both fresh and set states at concentrations of 50 mg/ml and 100 mg/ml.
    • Both materials were ineffective at killing C. albicans after 1 hour but were fungicidal at 24 and 48 hours, with no significant difference between the two materials at any concentration or time point.
• MTA-Angelus and ProRoot MTA are used in endodontic treatments due to their sealing ability, biocompatibility, and antimicrobial effects, despite some handling disadvantages.
    • MTA-Angelus has a strong fungicidal effect against C. albicans and contains arsenic levels below the ISO 9917-1 standard, making it a viable alternative to ProRoot MTA.
• The study used a tube-dilution susceptibility test to evaluate antifungal activity, allowing direct contact between C. albicans and the materials, which may provide a more realistic interaction compared to other methods.
    • The antifungal activity is likely due to the presence of calcium hydroxide and increased pH from hydroxyl ion release, but further in vivo studies are needed to confirm these findings.
</summary>

<summary>
* The study investigates motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb of stroke patients, focusing on visuomotor coordination and proprioceptive sense.
  * Fifty hemiparetic stroke patients and 40 age- and sex-matched control subjects participated, with tests conducted on the hand ipsilateral to the damaged hemisphere.
* Ipsilateral motor deficits are evident in stroke patients, with lower accuracy in tracking tasks compared to control subjects.
  * Sensory deficits, particularly in proprioceptive sense, are also observed, with higher reposition errors in stroke patients.
* A significant correlation exists between ipsilateral motor and sensory deficits, suggesting interconnected mechanisms.
  * The study proposes that bilateral hemisphere activation and transcallosal transfer disturbances may contribute to these deficits.
* The findings highlight the importance of considering both motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral side of stroke patients.
  * Previous studies have focused more on motor deficits, but this study emphasizes the role of sensory deficits in task performance difficulties.
* Recovery of ipsilateral motor deficits is noted within one month post-stroke, but complete recovery is not achieved.
  * Future research is needed to explore the recovery of ipsilateral sensory deficits and the impact of lesion location and extent.
* The study acknowledges limitations, such as not identifying specific lesion locations and damage extent.
  * Further studies are required to understand detailed mechanisms of movement and sensory deficits beyond proprioceptive sense.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study focuses on the development of nanoparticles for targeted delivery of biopharmaceutical agents, addressing challenges like non-specific cell uptake.
  • Researchers have developed pH-triggered, PEGylated siRNA nanoparticles for passive targeting of liver and tumor cells, demonstrating potential for RNAi therapeutic approaches.

• A post-coupling methodology was adapted to introduce integrin-targeting peptide motifs onto nanoparticles, enhancing integrin receptor-mediated cellular uptake.
  • The study highlights the use of cyclic pentapeptide constructs for effective intracellular delivery through integrin receptor binding, with controls to ensure receptor-specific uptake.

• The research emphasizes the importance of optimizing nanoparticle properties for receptor-mediated delivery, proposing standard assays to confirm receptor-specific ligand functionality.
  • The study suggests that nanoparticle dimensions, charge, and ligand coverage are crucial for successful receptor-mediated cell entry, with further research needed to validate these guidelines.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Millennium Cohort Study is the largest prospective study by the Department of Defense, initiated in 2001 to evaluate health outcomes related to military service.
  • The study initially enrolled 77,047 participants, with follow-up surveys conducted in 2004 and 2007.
  • Data collected included health conditions, mental health symptoms, sleep patterns, and demographic information.
  • The study was approved by the Naval Health Research Center Institutional Review Board and complied with federal regulations.

• The study focused on incident diabetes, excluding participants with diabetes at baseline and those with missing data.
  • Sleep variables analyzed included trouble sleeping, sleep duration, and sleep apnea.
  • Mental health conditions like PTSD and depression were assessed for their impact on diabetes risk.
  • Generalized estimating equations were used to analyze associations between diabetes and various factors.

• Findings indicated that sleep characteristics are associated with new-onset diabetes, independent of mental health conditions.
  • Trouble sleeping and sleep apnea were linked to higher diabetes odds.
  • Military service characteristics like deployment and pay grade also influenced diabetes risk.
  • Mental health conditions such as PTSD and panic disorder were associated with higher diabetes risk.

• The study's limitations include reliance on self-reported data and lack of adjustment for diet or family history.
  • Despite these limitations, the study provides insights into the relationship between sleep, mental health, and diabetes risk.
  • The findings are relevant to younger, healthy populations similar to military personnel.
  • Further research is needed to confirm these findings and explore diabetes prevention strategies.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study retrospectively reviewed radiological and clinical findings of 13 patients with mesenchymal hamartoma of the liver.
  • The institutional review board approved the study and waived informed consent.
  • A hospital information system identified patients over a 15-year period.

• CT scans were used to evaluate the tumors, classifying them into three types based on cystic components.
  • Types included multiseptated cystic, mixed cystic and solid, and solid tumors.
  • CT scans assessed tumor location, size, septa presence, attenuation, contrast-enhancement, and calcification.

• Ultrasonographic scans were available for nine patients, with color or power Doppler used in seven.
  • US images evaluated capsule presence, cystic portion content, septal thickness, and solid portion echogenicity.
  • Mesenchymal stroma, duct proliferation, hepatocytes, and vascular proliferation were semi-quantitatively evaluated.

• The study included seven boys and six girls, aged 6 months to 7 years 6 months.
  • Patients presented with abdominal distension, palpable mass, or incidentally detected tumors.
  • Tumors were located in the right lobe in nine patients and left lobe in four.

• Tumor sizes ranged from 1.8 to 20 cm, with 85% larger than 10 cm.
  • No significant size difference was found among the three CT types.
  • The amount of hepatocytes varied significantly among tumor types.

• Mesenchymal hamartoma is the second most common benign hepatic tumor in children.
  • It accounts for 8% of all hepatic tumors in children.
  • Histologically, it appears as a disordered arrangement of mesenchyme, bile ducts, and hepatocytes.

• The study found a wide spectrum of radiological features in mesenchymal hamartomas.
  • Tumors ranged from multiseptated cystic to mixed solid and cystic, and even solid tumors.
  • Radiological differential diagnosis should include various hepatic tumors.

• The study noted the absence of a tumor capsule in mesenchymal hamartomas.
  • This can aid in differential diagnosis from other tumors.
  • Heterogeneous enhancement is another distinguishing feature.

• The study concluded that mesenchymal hamartomas in children show diverse radiological features.
  • The spectrum includes multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid tumors.
